Q5/- What is the Difference between the sleep and join method .

Sleep()
------
If a thread doesnâ€™t want to perform any operation for a particular amount of time, 
then we should go for sleep() method.

Example

public class Time implements Runnable{
	
	@Override
	public void run() {

		for(int i =0; i<5; i++) {
			System.out.println(i);
			try {
				Thread.sleep(1000);
			} catch (InterruptedException e) {
				// TODO Auto-generated catch block
				e.printStackTrace();
			}
		}
	
		
	}

	public static void main(String[] args) {

		Time t = new Time();
		
		Thread t1 = new Thread(t);
		t1.start();
		
		System.out.println("end of main");
		
	}

	

}

Join()
------
If a thread wants to wait until completing thread some other threads, 
then we should go for join.

Example

public class Join implements Runnable{
	 int sum;
	@Override
	public void run() {
     
		for(int i=0; i<5; i++) {
			System.out.println("inside run");
			sum = sum+i; 
		}
	}

	public static void main(String[] args) {

		Join j1 = new Join();
		Thread t1 = new Thread(j1);
		t1.start();
		try {
			t1.join();
		} catch (InterruptedException e) {
			// TODO Auto-generated catch block
			e.printStackTrace();
		}
		
		int result = j1.sum;
		for(int i=0; i<5; i++) {
			System.out.println("inside main");
		 System.out.println(result);
		}
		
		System.out.println("end of main");
		
	}

}
